line: There are names designating nothing else but a particular disease. Plague is certainly
label: paragraph

line: not one of those: rather than a name, it is a list of associations, a cultural
label: paragraph

line: phenomenon that has helped (or dishelped) shaping human history, not only
label: paragraph

line: demography, as one would expect, but also politics and economy, art and literature,
label: paragraph

line: psychology.
label: paragraph

line: The amazing series of Oxford University Press’ „Very Short Introductions“ (more
label: paragraph

line: than 300 titles as yet!) is expected to provide basic information and overview of
label: paragraph

line: (often) complex topics. However, this edition, written by Paul Slack, Emeritus
label: paragraph

line: Professor of Early Modern Social History at Oxford University, Fellow of British
label: paragraph

line: Academy, ex Principal of Linacre College, and the author of The Impact of Plague in
label: paragraph

line: Tudor and Stuart England (1990) and other works, has pleasantly surprised even the
label: paragraph

line: most spoiled readers: rather than compiling a chronicle or mere chronography, Paul
label: paragraph

line: Slack re-created a long continuum of time in a vivid and dynamic way, similar to a
label: paragraph

line: fiction, but well ducumented and thus powerful. By his own words, „Mine has been
label: paragraph

line: an historian’s view […], designed to show how [the reactions to plague] were all
label: paragraph

line: shaped by the circumstances.“ In the best tradition of the Les Annales school of the
label: paragraph

line: second half of the 20th century, Paul Slack has shaped a real social history of plague,
label: paragraph

line: devoting more attention to the everyday life (and death), using mostly Italian,
label: paragraph

line: English, French, and Spanish sources and literature. In that particular (and
label: paragraph

line: necessarily limited) framework, Dubrovnik appears as „Venetian port“, and, when it
label: paragraph

line: comes to the analysis of art pieces related to epidemics, a lot of attention is devoted
label: paragraph

line: to Camus and Bergman, but there is no mention of Borislav Pekić’s novel Besnilo
label: paragraph

line: („Rabies“; later filmed, too), for instance.
label: paragraph

line: The structure of Slack’s „Introduction“ to plague, already steps off the usual road of
label: paragraph

line: presenting historical matters: the author first deals with the name („important
label: paragraph

line: because it creates identity“), dipping immediately into the toughest question – of
label: paragraph

line: diagnosing plague and comparing epidemics from various epochs. Here, the author
label: paragraph

line: analyses the most recent scientific literature and frames the most reasonable and
label: paragraph

line: probable conclusion on the plague’s variations not in symptoms, but in epidemic
label: paragraph

line: pathways over time and space. (Hereby, the term „frame“ is liked by Paul Slack in
label: paragraph

line: particular, taken over from Charles Rosenberg and refering to the reaction of society
label: paragraph

line: to the „picture“ of a disease.)
label: paragraph

line: In Chapter 2, three major plague pandemics are discussed: the first is supposed to
label: paragraph

line: be related to c. 541-c. 750 in Mediterranean and Europe, the second to the period
label: paragraph

line: of 1347-c. 1771 in Europe, and the third, beginning in 1894 in India and China
label: paragraph

line: and still lasting. According to Paul Slack, all single epidemics, even if distributed
label: paragraph

line: over a long period of (re)appearances, can be explained by those three pandemic
label: paragraph

line: phenomena. Curious is that, while in the 14th-century Europe, the mortality was
label: paragraph

line: about 50-60 %, in the later epidemics, the mortality reached 20 % (17th-18th c.)
label: paragraph

line: or even less.
label: paragraph

line: Of course, the major sub-topic of the booklet must be the Black Death in the mid
label: paragraph

line: 14th century, the impact of which is the central theme of Chapter 3, while the
label: paragraph

line: „private horrors“ caused by this most horrible epidemics in human history, of
label: paragraph

line: Chapter 4. Since doctors were not particularly able to provide assistance to the
label: paragraph

line: diseased, the folk, logically, oriented more toward the saints-protectors, of which
label: paragraph

line: especially beloved was St. Rochus. (In Istria, in Western Croatia, Rochus had not
label: paragraph

line: been only the most venerated in the time of plague, with some 30 churches build
label: paragraph

line: either ex voto or in greatfulness, but his cult was revived during the later epidemics
label: paragraph

line: of cholera, in the 19th century.)
label: paragraph

line: In Chapter 5, dealt is with the emergence of public health measures, with all the
label: paragraph

line: difficulties related to cultural differences in accepting their forced imposal. Actually,
label: paragraph

line: one might say that plague „invented“ public health and that, particularly because of
label: paragraph

line: that fact, plague has to be considered important „teacher“ on the transmission of
label: paragraph

line: diseases, on the importance of personal hygienic habits and flexibility and
label: paragraph

line: preparedness of a local community (as proved in Marseilles in the 14th c.). Finally,
label: paragraph

line: Chapter 6, entitled „Enduring images“, lists and comments on the long series of the
label: paragraph

line: pieces of art and literature, provoked by or devoted to plague. Fascinating sounds
label: paragraph

line: how motives and taste were changing in visual arts, introducing and demistifying
label: paragraph

line: death (including the famous motive of dance macabre), and how fashion books on
label: paragraph

line: ars moriendi entered literature and started to prepare readers for a more peaceful
label: paragraph

line: end. In a short conclusion, Slack, like every serious scholar, humbly relativises his
label: paragraph

line: work and theses, stressing the impredictability of plague, but also the lessons we
label: paragraph

line: have learned from the epidemics in human history.
label: paragraph

line: We certainly do not know everything about the plague epidemics of our past: we do
label: paragraph

line: not know whether central Asia is really the reservoir of rats responsible for major
label: paragraph

line: European epidemics; or whether the quick propagating of the disease, seen in only
label: paragraph

line: some epidemics, may have been related to the life habits of the black rat or to the
label: paragraph

line: „direct“ transmission from the flea to the man. However, it is quite certain that,
label: paragraph

line: after having read Paul Slack’s „Very Short Introduction“, we are not only more
label: paragraph

line: informed, but far more impressed by the broadness of changes plague epidemics
label: paragraph

line: provoked, as illustrated in Slack’s „miniatures“ on the flagellants, the culpriting of
label: paragraph

line: Jews, the sudden „advancement“ of the poor after the dissappearance of their lords
label: paragraph

line: (with the resulting increase of wages, decline of serfdom, change of clothing fashion,
label: paragraph

line: reduction of the number of children in order to keep new higher standard, etc.).
label: paragraph

line: At the certain moment, Slack states that „One of the continuities in the history of
label: paragraph

line: plague which justify this book was its educative function.“ A proper, real history is
label: paragraph

line: never just a (hi)story: for if it is proper, it must teach in order to avoid repeating
label: paragraph

line: mistakes, and it must inspire in order to shorten the way to the solutions of similar
label: paragraph

line: problems. Paul Slack’s history of plague is proper not only because we are aware that
label: paragraph

line: plague is a re-emerging disease: it is proper because the author’s wit and persuasive
label: paragraph

line: style, as well as the documentedness of the narrative, make us believe the story of
label: paragraph

line: plague be important part of the most delicate process of human progress.
